supporting.text: Scientific research has found no evidence that pangolin scales have any medicinal properties that can cure diseases.

supporting.text: Pangolin scales are primarily composed of keratin, the same protein found in human hair and nails, which has no known therapeutic effects.

attacks.text: Pangolin scales are primarily composed of keratin, the same protein found in human hair and nails, which has no known therapeutic effects.
Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) has used pangolin scales for centuries to treat conditions like poor circulation and lactation issues, suggesting some perceived efficacy.
Modern clinical studies have found no evidence supporting the medicinal efficacy of pangolin scales, and TCM's historical use may be based on placebo effects or outdated beliefs.
Keratin-based materials can have bioactive properties when processed or combined with other compounds, so dismissing pangolin scales purely based on keratin content may be oversimplified.
No peer-reviewed studies demonstrate that processed keratin from pangolin scales has unique bioactive properties compared to other keratin sources, making their use medically unjustified.
